How Faithful is your Synthetic Data?
Sample-level Metrics for Evaluating and Auditing Generative Models

Ahmed M. Alaa    Boris van Breugel    Evgeny Saveliev    Mihaela van der Schaar
Abstract

Devising domain- and model-agnostic evaluation metrics for generative models is an important and as yet unresolved problem. Most existing metrics, which were tailored solely to the image synthesis application, exhibit a limited capacity for diagnosing modes of failure of generative models across broader application domains. In this paper, we introduce a 3-dimensional metric, (α𝛼\alpha-Precision, β𝛽\beta-Recall, Authenticity), that characterizes the fidelity, diversity and generalization performance of any generative model in a wide variety of application domains. Our metric unifies statistical divergence measures with precision-recall analysis, enabling sample- and distribution-level diagnoses of model fidelity and diversity. We introduce generalization as an additional dimension for model performance that quantifies the extent to which a model copies training data—a crucial performance indicator when modeling sensitive and private data. The three metric components are interpretable probabilistic quantities, and can be estimated via sample-level binary classification. The sample-level nature of our metric inspires a novel use case which we call model auditing, wherein we judge the quality of individual samples generated by a (black-box) model, discarding low-quality samples and hence improving the overall model performance in a post-hoc manner.

Machine Learning, ICML

1 Introduction

Intuitively, it would seem that evaluating the likelihood function of a generative model is all it takes to assess its performance. As it turns out, the problem of evaluating generative models is far more complicated. This is not only because state-of-the-art models, such as Variational Autoencoders (VAE) (Kingma & Welling, 2013) and Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) (Goodfellow et al., 2014), do not possess tractable likelihood functions, but also because the likelihood score itself is a flawed measure of performance—it scales badly in high dimensions, and it obscures distinct modes of model failure into a single uninterpretable score (Theis et al., 2015). Absent domain-agnostic metrics, earlier work focused on crafting domain-specific scores, e.g., the Inception score in (Salimans et al., 2016), with an exclusive emphasis on image data (Lucic et al., 2018).

In this paper, we follow an alternative approach to evaluating generative models, where instead of assessing the generative distribution by looking at all synthetic samples collectively to compute likelihood or statistical divergence, we classify each sample individually as being of high or low quality. Our metric represents the performance of a generative model as a point in a 3-dimensional space—each dimension corresponds to a distinct quality of the model. These qualities are: Fidelity, Diversity and Generalization. Fidelity measures the quality of a model’s synthetic samples, and Diversity is the extent to which these samples cover the full variability of real samples, whereas Generalization quantifies the extent to which a model overfits (copies) training data. All three measures are defined as binary conditions that can be inspected for individual samples in real and synthetic data.

Our main contribution is a refined precision-recall analysis of the Fidelity and Diversity performance of generative models that is grounded in the notion of minimum volume sets (Scott & Nowak, 2006). More precisely, we introduce the α𝛼\alpha-Precision and β𝛽\beta-Recall as generalizations of the standard precision and recall metrics introduced in (Sajjadi et al., 2018) to quantify model Fidelity and Diversity, respectively. Our proposed metrics inspect model performance within different density level sets for real and synthetic distributions, which enables more detailed diagnostics of the failure modes of generative models. In addition, we introduce the Authenticity metric to quantify Generalization, i.e., the likelihood of a synthetic sample being copied from training data, using a formal hypothesis test for data copying. This additional evaluation dimension helps differentiate between models that truly “invent” new samples and ones that generate ostensibly high-quality data by memorizing training samples.

How is our metric different? To highlight the qualities of synthetic data captured by our metric, we first provide an informal definition of its components. Our proposed precision-recall analysis operates on α𝛼\alpha- and β𝛽\beta-minimum volume sets of the data distributions—that is, we assume that a fraction 1−α1𝛼1-\alpha (or 1−β1𝛽1-\beta) of the real (and synthetic) data are “outliers”, and α𝛼\alpha (or β𝛽\beta) are “typical”. α𝛼\alpha-Precision is the fraction of synthetic samples that resemble the “most typical” fraction α𝛼\alpha of real samples, whereas β𝛽\beta-Recall is the fraction of real samples covered by the most typical fraction β𝛽\beta of synthetic samples. The two metrics are evaluated for all α,β∈[0,1]𝛼𝛽01\alpha,\beta\in[0,1], providing entire precision and recall curves instead of single numbers. To compute both metrics, we embed the (real and synthetic) data into hyperspheres with most samples concentrated around the centers, i.e., the real and generative distributions (ℙrsubscriptℙ𝑟\mathbb{P}_{r} and ℙgsubscriptℙ𝑔\mathbb{P}_{g}) has spherical-shaped supports. In this transformed space, typical samples would be located near the centers of the spheres, whereas outliers would be closer to the boundaries as illustrated in Figure 1.

If one thinks of standard precision and recall as “hard” binary classifiers of real and synthetic data, our proposed metrics can be thought of as soft-boundary classifiers that do not only compare the supports of ℙrsubscriptℙ𝑟\mathbb{P}_{r} and ℙgsubscriptℙ𝑔\mathbb{P}_{g}, but also assesses whether both distributions are calibrated. Precision and recall metrics are special cases of α𝛼\alpha-Precision and β𝛽\beta-Recall for α=β=1𝛼𝛽1\alpha=\beta=1. As we show later, our new metric definitions solve many of the drawbacks of standard precision-recall analysis, such as lack of robustness to outliers and failure to detect distributional mismatches (Naeem et al., 2020). They also enable detailed diagnostics of different types of model failure, such as mode collapse and mode invention. Moreover, optimal values of our metrics are achieved only when ℙrsubscriptℙ𝑟\mathbb{P}_{r} and ℙgsubscriptℙ𝑔\mathbb{P}_{g} are identical, thereby eliminating the need to augment the model evaluation procedure with additional measures of statistical divergence (e.g., KL divergence, Fréchet distance (Heusel et al., 2017), and maximum mean discrepancy (MMD) (Sutherland et al., 2016)). A detailed survey of existing evaluation metrics is provided in the Appendix.

Previous works relied on pre-trained embeddings (e.g., ImageNet feature extractors (Deng et al., 2009). In this work, we utilize (hyperspheric) feature embeddings that are model- and domain-agnostic, and are tailored to our metric definitions. These embeddings can be completely bespoke to raw data or applied to pre-trained embeddings. This enables our metric to remain operable in application domains where no pre-trained representations are available.

Overfitting is a crucial mode of failure of generative models, especially when modeling sensitive data with privacy requirements (Yoon et al., 2020), but it has been overlooked in previous work which focused exclusively on assessing fidelity and diversity (Brock et al., 2018). As we show in our experiments (Section 5), by accounting for generalization performance, our metric provide a fuller picture of the quality of synthetic data. Precisely, we show that some of the celebrated generative models score highly for fidelity and diversity simply because they memorize real samples, rendering them inadequate for privacy-sensitive applications.

Model auditing as a novel use case. The sample-level nature of our metrics inspires the new use case of model auditing, where we judge individual synthetic samples by their quality, and reject samples that have low fidelity or are unauthentic. In Section 5, we show that model audits can improve model outputs in a post-hoc fashion without any modifications to the model itself, and demonstrate this use case in synthesizing clinical data for COVID-19 patients.

2 Evaluating and Auditing Generative Models

We denote real and generated data as Xr∼ℙrsimilar-tosubscript𝑋𝑟subscriptℙ𝑟X_{r}\sim\mathbb{P}_{r} and Xg∼ℙgsimilar-tosubscript𝑋𝑔subscriptℙ𝑔X_{g}\sim\mathbb{P}_{g}, respectively, where Xr,Xg∈𝒳subscript𝑋𝑟subscript𝑋𝑔𝒳X_{r},X_{g}\in\mathcal{X}, with ℙrsubscriptℙ𝑟\mathbb{P}_{r} and ℙgsubscriptℙ𝑔\mathbb{P}_{g} being the real and generative distributions. The real and synthetic data sets are 𝒟r​e​a​l={Xr,i}i=1nsubscript𝒟𝑟𝑒𝑎𝑙superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑋𝑟𝑖𝑖1𝑛\mathcal{D}_{real}=\{X_{r,i}\}_{i=1}^{n} and 𝒟s​y​n​t​h={Xg,j}j=1msubscript𝒟𝑠𝑦𝑛𝑡ℎsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑋𝑔𝑗𝑗1𝑚\mathcal{D}_{synth}=\{X_{g,j}\}_{j=1}^{m}.

2.1 What makes a good synthetic data set?

Our goal is to construct a metric 𝓔​(𝒟r​e​a​l,𝒟s​y​n​t​h)𝓔subscript𝒟𝑟𝑒𝑎𝑙subscript𝒟𝑠𝑦𝑛𝑡ℎ\boldsymbol{\mathcal{E}}(\mathcal{D}_{real},\mathcal{D}_{synth}) for the quality of 𝒟s​y​n​t​hsubscript𝒟𝑠𝑦𝑛𝑡ℎ\mathcal{D}_{synth} in order to (i) evaluate the performance of the underlying generative model, and (ii) audit the model outputs by discarding low-quality samples, thereby improving the overall quality of 𝒟s​y​n​t​hsubscript𝒟𝑠𝑦𝑛𝑡ℎ\mathcal{D}_{synth}. In order for 𝓔𝓔\boldsymbol{\mathcal{E}} to fulfill the evaluation and auditing tasks, it must satisfy the following desiderata: (1) it should be able to disentangle the different modes of failure of ℙgsubscriptℙ𝑔\mathbb{P}_{g} through interpretable measures of performance, and (2) it should be sample-wise computable, i.e., we should be able to tell if a given (individual) synthetic sample Xg∼ℙgsimilar-tosubscript𝑋𝑔subscriptℙ𝑔X_{g}\sim\mathbb{P}_{g} is of a low quality.

Having outlined the desiderata for our sought-after evaluation metric, we identify three independent qualities of synthetic data that the metric 𝓔𝓔\boldsymbol{\mathcal{E}} should be able to quantify.

  1. 1.

    Fidelity—the generated samples resemble real samples from ℙrsubscriptℙ𝑟\mathbb{P}_{r}. A high-fidelity synthetic data set should contain “realistic” samples, e.g. visually-realistic images.

  2. 2.

    Diversity—the generated samples are diverse enough to cover the variability of real data, i.e., a model should be able to generate a wide variety of good samples.

  3. 3.

    Generalization—the generated samples should not be mere copies of the (real) samples in training data, i.e., models that overfit to 𝒟r​e​a​lsubscript𝒟𝑟𝑒𝑎𝑙\mathcal{D}_{real} are not truly “generative”.

In Section 3, we propose a three-dimensional evaluation metric 𝓔𝓔\boldsymbol{\mathcal{E}} that captures all of the qualities above. Our proposed metric can be succinctly described as follows:

𝓔≜(α-Precision⏟F​i​d​e​l​i​t​y,β-Recall⏟D​i​v​e​r​s​i​t​y,Authenticity⏟G​e​n​e​r​a​l​i​z​a​t​i​o​n).≜𝓔subscript⏟α-Precision𝐹𝑖𝑑𝑒𝑙𝑖𝑡𝑦subscript⏟β-Recall𝐷𝑖𝑣𝑒𝑟𝑠𝑖𝑡𝑦subscript⏟Authenticity𝐺𝑒𝑛𝑒𝑟𝑎𝑙𝑖𝑧𝑎𝑡𝑖𝑜𝑛\displaystyle\boldsymbol{\mathcal{E}}\triangleq(\underbrace{\mbox{$\alpha$-Precision}}_{Fidelity},\,\,\underbrace{\mbox{$\beta$-Recall}}_{Diversity},\,\,\underbrace{\mbox{Authenticity}}_{Generalization}). (1)

The α𝛼\alpha-Precision and β𝛽\beta-Recall metrics are generalizations of the conventional notions of precision and recall used in binary classification analysis (Flach & Kull, 2015). Precision measures the rate by which the model synthesizes “realistic-looking” samples, whereas the recall measures the fraction of real samples that are covered by ℙgsubscriptℙ𝑔\mathbb{P}_{g}. Authenticity measures the fraction of synthetic samples that are invented by the model and not copied from the training data.

2.2 Evaluation and Auditing pipelines

We now briefly summarize the steps involved in the evaluation and auditing tasks. Since statistical comparisons of complex data types in the raw input space 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} are difficult, the evaluation pipeline starts by embedding Xrsubscript𝑋𝑟X_{r} and Xgsubscript𝑋𝑔X_{g} into a meaningful feature space through an evaluation embedding ΦΦ\Phi, and evaluating 𝓔𝓔\boldsymbol{\mathcal{E}} on the embedded features (Figure 2(a)). In Section 4, we show that the definitions of α𝛼\alpha-Precision and β𝛽\beta-Recall based on the notion of minimum volume sets inspire a natural construction for the representation ΦΦ\Phi.

In the post-hoc model auditing task, we compute the sample-level metrics for each Xg,jsubscript𝑋𝑔𝑗X_{g,j} in 𝒟s​y​n​t​hsubscript𝒟𝑠𝑦𝑛𝑡ℎ\mathcal{D}_{synth}, and discard samples with low authenticity and/or precision scores, which results in a “curated” synthetic data set with an improved overall performance. When granted direct access to the model ℙgsubscriptℙ𝑔\mathbb{P}_{g}, the auditor acts as a rejection sampler that repeatedly draws samples from ℙgsubscriptℙ𝑔\mathbb{P}_{g}, only accepting ones with high precision and authenticity (Figure 2(b)). Model auditing is possible through our metrics as they can be used to evaluate the quality of individual synthetic samples; the same task cannot be carried out with statistical divergence measures that compare the overall real and generative distributions.

3 α𝛼\alpha-Precision, β𝛽\beta-Recall and Authenticity

3.1 Definitions and notations

Let X~r=Φ​(Xr)subscript~𝑋𝑟Φsubscript𝑋𝑟\widetilde{X}_{r}=\Phi(X_{r}) and X~g=Φ​(Xg)subscript~𝑋𝑔Φsubscript𝑋𝑔\widetilde{X}_{g}=\Phi(X_{g}) be the embedded real and synthetic data. For simplicity, we will use ℙrsubscriptℙ𝑟\mathbb{P}_{r} and ℙgsubscriptℙ𝑔\mathbb{P}_{g} to refer to distributions over raw and embedded features interchangeably. Let 𝒮r=supp​(ℙr)subscript𝒮𝑟suppsubscriptℙ𝑟\mathcal{S}_{r}=\mbox{supp}(\mathbb{P}_{r}) and 𝒮g=supp​(ℙg)subscript𝒮𝑔suppsubscriptℙ𝑔\mathcal{S}_{g}=\mbox{supp}(\mathbb{P}_{g}), where supp​(ℙ)suppℙ\mbox{supp}(\mathbb{P}) is the support of ℙℙ\mathbb{P}. Central to our proposed metrics is a more general notion for the support of ℙℙ\mathbb{P}, which we dub the α𝛼\alpha-support. We define the α𝛼\alpha-support as the minimum volume subset of 𝒮=supp​(ℙ)𝒮suppℙ\mathcal{S}=\mbox{supp}(\mathbb{P}) that supports a probability mass of α𝛼\alpha (Polonik, 1997; Scott & Nowak, 2006), i.e.,

𝒮α≜mins⊆𝒮⁡V​(s),s.t.ℙ​(s)=α,formulae-sequence≜superscript𝒮𝛼subscript𝑠𝒮𝑉𝑠𝑠𝑡ℙ𝑠𝛼\displaystyle\mathcal{S}^{\alpha}\triangleq\min_{s\,\subseteq\,\mathcal{S}}\,V(s),\,s.t.\,\,\mathbb{P}(s)=\alpha, (2)

where V​(s)𝑉𝑠V(s) is the volume (Lebesgue measure) of s𝑠s, and α∈[0,1]𝛼01\alpha\in[0,1]. One can think of an α𝛼\alpha-support as dividing the full support of ℙℙ\mathbb{P} into “normal” samples concentrated in 𝒮αsuperscript𝒮𝛼\mathcal{S}^{\alpha}, and “outliers” residing in 𝒮¯αsuperscript¯𝒮𝛼\bar{\mathcal{S}}^{\alpha}, where 𝒮=𝒮α∪𝒮¯α𝒮superscript𝒮𝛼superscript¯𝒮𝛼\mathcal{S}=\mathcal{S}^{\alpha}\cup\bar{\mathcal{S}}^{\alpha}.

Finally, define d​(X,𝒟r​e​a​l)𝑑𝑋subscript𝒟𝑟𝑒𝑎𝑙d(X,\mathcal{D}_{real}) as the distance between X𝑋X and the closest sample in the training data set 𝒟r​e​a​lsubscript𝒟𝑟𝑒𝑎𝑙\mathcal{D}_{real}, i.e.,

d​(X,𝒟r​e​a​l)=min1≤i≤n⁡d​(X,Xr,i),𝑑𝑋subscript𝒟𝑟𝑒𝑎𝑙subscript1𝑖𝑛𝑑𝑋subscript𝑋𝑟𝑖\displaystyle d(X,\mathcal{D}_{real})=\min_{1\leq i\leq n}d(X,X_{r,i}), (3)

where d𝑑d is a distance metric defined over the input space 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}.

3.2 Sample-level evaluation metrics

3.2.1 α𝛼\alpha-Precision and β𝛽\beta-Recall

𝜶𝜶\boldsymbol{\alpha}-Precision. The conventional Precision metric is defined as the probability that a generated sample is supported by the real distribution, i.e. ℙ​(X~g∈𝒮r)ℙsubscript~𝑋𝑔subscript𝒮𝑟\mathbb{P}(\widetilde{X}_{g}\in\mathcal{S}_{r}) (Sajjadi et al., 2018). We propose a more refined measure of sample fidelity, called the α𝛼\alpha-Precision metric (Pαsubscript𝑃𝛼P_{\alpha}), which we define as follows:

Pαsubscript𝑃𝛼\displaystyle P_{\alpha}\,\, ≜ℙ​(X~g∈𝒮rα),for α∈[0,1].≜absentℙsubscript~𝑋𝑔subscriptsuperscript𝒮𝛼𝑟for α∈[0,1].\displaystyle\triangleq\,\,\mathbb{P}(\widetilde{X}_{g}\in\mathcal{S}^{\alpha}_{r}),\,\mbox{for $\alpha\in[0,1]$.} (4)

That is, Pαsubscript𝑃𝛼P_{\alpha} is the probability that a synthetic sample resides in the α𝛼\alpha-support of the real distribution.

𝜷𝜷\boldsymbol{\beta}-Recall. To assess diversity in synthetic data, we propose the β𝛽\beta-Recall metric as a generalization of the conventional Recall metric. Formally, we define the β𝛽\beta-Recall as follows:

Rβsubscript𝑅𝛽\displaystyle R_{\beta}\,\, ≜ℙ​(X~r∈𝒮gβ),for β∈[0,1],≜absentℙsubscript~𝑋𝑟subscriptsuperscript𝒮𝛽𝑔for β∈[0,1],\displaystyle\triangleq\,\,\mathbb{P}(\widetilde{X}_{r}\in\mathcal{S}^{\beta}_{g}),\,\mbox{for $\beta\in[0,1]$,} (5)

i.e., Rβsubscript𝑅𝛽R_{\beta} is the fraction of real samples that reside within the β𝛽\beta-support of the generative distribution.

Interpreting α𝛼\boldsymbol{\alpha}-Precision and β𝛽\boldsymbol{\beta}-Recall. To interpret (4) and (5), we revisit the notion of α𝛼\alpha-support. From (2), we know that an α𝛼\alpha-support hosts the most densely packed probability mass α𝛼\alpha in a distribution, hence 𝒮rαsubscriptsuperscript𝒮𝛼𝑟\mathcal{S}^{\alpha}_{r} and 𝒮gβsubscriptsuperscript𝒮𝛽𝑔\mathcal{S}^{\beta}_{g} always concentrate around the modes of ℙrsubscriptℙ𝑟\mathbb{P}_{r} and ℙgsubscriptℙ𝑔\mathbb{P}_{g} (Figure 3); samples residing outside of 𝒮rαsubscriptsuperscript𝒮𝛼𝑟\mathcal{S}^{\alpha}_{r} and 𝒮gβsubscriptsuperscript𝒮𝛽𝑔\mathcal{S}^{\beta}_{g} can be thought of as outliers. In this sense, Pαsubscript𝑃𝛼P_{\alpha} and Rβsubscript𝑅𝛽R_{\beta} do not count outliers when assessing fidelity and diversity. That is, the α𝛼\alpha-Precision score deems a synthetic sample to be of a high fidelity not only if it looks “realistic”, but also if it looks “typical”. Similarly, β𝛽\beta-Recall counts a real sample as being covered by ℙgsubscriptℙ𝑔\mathbb{P}_{g} only if it is not an outlier in ℙgsubscriptℙ𝑔\mathbb{P}_{g}. By sweeping the values of α𝛼\alpha and β𝛽\beta from 0 to 1, we obtain a varying definition of which samples are typical and which are outliers—this gives us entire Pαsubscript𝑃𝛼P_{\alpha} and Rβsubscript𝑅𝛽R_{\beta} curves as illustrated in Figure 3.

Generalizing precision-recall analysis. Unlike standard precision and recall, Pαsubscript𝑃𝛼P_{\alpha} and Rβsubscript𝑅𝛽R_{\beta} take into account not only the supports of ℙrsubscriptℙ𝑟\mathbb{P}_{r} and ℙgsubscriptℙ𝑔\mathbb{P}_{g}, but also their densities. Standard precision-recall are single points on the Pαsubscript𝑃𝛼P_{\alpha} and Rβsubscript𝑅𝛽R_{\beta} curves; they coincide with Pαsubscript𝑃𝛼P_{\alpha} and Rβsubscript𝑅𝛽R_{\beta} evaluated on full supports (P1subscript𝑃1P_{1} and R1subscript𝑅1R_{1}). By defining our metrics with respect to α𝛼\alpha- and β𝛽\beta-supports, we do not treat all samples equally, but assign higher importance to samples in “denser” regions in 𝒮rsubscript𝒮𝑟\mathcal{S}_{r} and 𝒮gsubscript𝒮𝑔\mathcal{S}_{g}. Pαsubscript𝑃𝛼P_{\alpha} and Rβsubscript𝑅𝛽R_{\beta} reflect the extent to which ℙrsubscriptℙ𝑟\mathbb{P}_{r} and ℙgsubscriptℙ𝑔\mathbb{P}_{g} are calibrated—i.e., good Pαsubscript𝑃𝛼P_{\alpha} and Rβsubscript𝑅𝛽R_{\beta} are achieved when ℙrsubscriptℙ𝑟\mathbb{P}_{r} and ℙgsubscriptℙ𝑔\mathbb{P}_{g} share the same modes and not just a common support.

The proposed Pαsubscript𝑃𝛼P_{\alpha} and Rβsubscript𝑅𝛽R_{\beta} metrics address major shortcomings of the commonly used P1subscript𝑃1P_{1} and R1subscript𝑅1R_{1}, among these are: lack of robustness to outliers, failure to detect matching distributions, and inability to diagnose different types of distributional failure (Naeem et al., 2020). Basically, ℙgsubscriptℙ𝑔\mathbb{P}_{g} will score perfectly on precision and recall (R1subscript𝑅1R_{1}=P1subscript𝑃1P_{1}=1) as long as it nails the support of ℙrsubscriptℙ𝑟\mathbb{P}_{r}, even if ℙrsubscriptℙ𝑟\mathbb{P}_{r} and ℙgsubscriptℙ𝑔\mathbb{P}_{g} place totally different densities on their common support. Figure 3 illustrates how our metrics remedy these shortcomings. While optimal R1subscript𝑅1R_{1} and P1subscript𝑃1P_{1} are achieved by arbitrarily mismatched densities, our Pαsubscript𝑃𝛼P_{\alpha} and Rβsubscript𝑅𝛽R_{\beta} curves are optimized only when ℙrsubscriptℙ𝑟\mathbb{P}_{r} and ℙgsubscriptℙ𝑔\mathbb{P}_{g} are identical as stated by Theorem 1.

Theorem 1. The α𝛼\alpha-Precision and β𝛽\beta-Recall satisfy the condition Pα/α=Rβ/β=1,∀α,β,formulae-sequencesubscript𝑃𝛼𝛼subscript𝑅𝛽𝛽1for-all𝛼𝛽P_{\alpha}/\alpha=R_{\beta}/\beta=1,\,\forall\,\alpha,\beta, iff the generative and real densities are equal, i.e., ℙg=ℙrsubscriptℙ𝑔subscriptℙ𝑟\mathbb{P}_{g}=\mathbb{P}_{r}.                                                         ■■\blacksquare

Theorem 1 says that a model is optimal if and only if both its Pαsubscript𝑃𝛼P_{\alpha} and Rβsubscript𝑅𝛽R_{\beta} are straight lines with unity slopes. It also implies that our metrics are not maximized if ℙrsubscriptℙ𝑟\mathbb{P}_{r} and ℙgsubscriptℙ𝑔\mathbb{P}_{g} have different densities, even if they share the same support.

Measuring statistical discrepancy with Pαsubscript𝑃𝛼\boldsymbol{P_{\alpha}} & Rβsubscript𝑅𝛽\boldsymbol{R_{\beta}}. While the Pαsubscript𝑃𝛼P_{\alpha} and Rβsubscript𝑅𝛽R_{\beta} curves provide a detailed view on a model’s fidelity and diversity, it is often more convenient to summarize performance in a single number. To this end, we define the mean absolute deviation of Pαsubscript𝑃𝛼P_{\alpha} and Rβsubscript𝑅𝛽R_{\beta} as:

Δ​Pα=∫01|Pα−α|​𝑑α,Δ​Rβ=∫01|Rβ−β|​𝑑β,formulae-sequenceΔsubscript𝑃𝛼superscriptsubscript01subscript𝑃𝛼𝛼differential-d𝛼Δsubscript𝑅𝛽superscriptsubscript01subscript𝑅𝛽𝛽differential-d𝛽\displaystyle\Delta P_{\alpha}=\int_{0}^{1}|P_{\alpha}-\alpha|\,d\alpha,\,\,\Delta R_{\beta}=\int_{0}^{1}|R_{\beta}-\beta|\,d\beta, (6)

where Δ​Pα∈[0,1/2]Δsubscript𝑃𝛼012\Delta P_{\alpha}\in[0,1/2] and Δ​Rβ∈[0,1/2]Δsubscript𝑅𝛽012\Delta R_{\beta}\in[0,1/2] quantify the extent to which Pαsubscript𝑃𝛼P_{\alpha} and Rβsubscript𝑅𝛽R_{\beta} deviate from their optimal values. We define the integrated Pαsubscript𝑃𝛼P_{\alpha} and Rβsubscript𝑅𝛽R_{\beta} metrics as I​Pα=1−2​Δ​Pα𝐼subscript𝑃𝛼12Δsubscript𝑃𝛼IP_{\alpha}=1-2\Delta P_{\alpha} and I​Rβ=1−2​Δ​Rβ𝐼subscript𝑅𝛽12Δsubscript𝑅𝛽IR_{\beta}=1-2\Delta R_{\beta}, both take values in [0,1]01[0,1]. From Theorem 1, I​Pα=I​Rβ=1𝐼subscript𝑃𝛼𝐼subscript𝑅𝛽1IP_{\alpha}=IR_{\beta}=1 only if ℙg=ℙrsubscriptℙ𝑔subscriptℙ𝑟\mathbb{P}_{g}=\mathbb{P}_{r}.

Together, I​Pα𝐼subscript𝑃𝛼IP_{\alpha} and I​Rβ𝐼subscript𝑅𝛽IR_{\beta} serve as measures of the discrepancy between ℙrsubscriptℙ𝑟\mathbb{P}_{r} and ℙgsubscriptℙ𝑔\mathbb{P}_{g}, eliminating the need to augment our precision-recall analysis with measures of statistical divergence. Moreover, unlike f𝑓f-divergence measures (e.g., KL divergence), the (I​Pα,I​Rβ𝐼subscript𝑃𝛼𝐼subscript𝑅𝛽IP_{\alpha},IR_{\beta}) metric disentangles fidelity and diversity into separate components, and its computation does not require that ℙrsubscriptℙ𝑟\mathbb{P}_{r} and ℙgsubscriptℙ𝑔\mathbb{P}_{g} share a common support.

3.2.2 Authenticity

Generalization is independent of precision and recall since a model can achieve perfect fidelity and diversity without truly generating any samples, simply by resampling training data. Unlike discriminative models for which generalization is easily tested via held-out data, evaluating generalization in generative models is not straightforward (Adlam et al., 2019; Meehan et al., 2020). We propose an authenticity score A∈[0,1]𝐴01A\in[0,1] to quantify the rate by which a model generates new samples. To pin down a mathematical definition for A𝐴A, we reformulate ℙgsubscriptℙ𝑔\mathbb{P}_{g} as a mixture of densities as follows:

ℙg=A⋅ℙg′+(1−A)⋅δg,ϵ,subscriptℙ𝑔⋅𝐴subscriptsuperscriptℙ′𝑔⋅1𝐴subscript𝛿𝑔italic-ϵ\displaystyle\mathbb{P}_{g}=A\cdot\mathbb{P}^{\prime}_{g}+(1-A)\cdot\delta_{g,\epsilon}, (7)

where ℙg′subscriptsuperscriptℙ′𝑔\mathbb{P}^{\prime}_{g} is the generative distribution conditioned on the synthetic samples not being copied, and δg,ϵsubscript𝛿𝑔italic-ϵ\delta_{g,\epsilon} is a noisy distribution over training data. In particular, we define δg,ϵsubscript𝛿𝑔italic-ϵ\delta_{g,\epsilon} as δg,ϵ=δg∗𝒩​(0,ϵ2)subscript𝛿𝑔italic-ϵ∗subscript𝛿𝑔𝒩0superscriptitalic-ϵ2\delta_{g,\epsilon}=\delta_{g}\ast\mathcal{N}(0,\epsilon^{2}), where δgsubscript𝛿𝑔\delta_{g} is a discrete distribution that places an unknown probability mass on each training data point in 𝒟r​e​a​lsubscript𝒟𝑟𝑒𝑎𝑙\mathcal{D}_{real}, ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is an arbitrarily small noise variance, and ∗∗\ast is the convolution operator. Essentially, (7) assumes that the model flips a (biased coin), pulling off a training sample with probability 1−A1𝐴1-A and adding some noise to it, or innovating a new sample with probability A𝐴A.

4 Estimating the Evaluation Metric

With all the metrics in Section 3 being defined on the sample level, we can obtain an estimate 𝓔^=(P^α,R^β,A^)bold-^𝓔subscript^𝑃𝛼subscript^𝑅𝛽^𝐴\boldsymbol{\widehat{\mathcal{E}}}=(\widehat{P}_{\alpha},\widehat{R}_{\beta},\widehat{A}) of the metric 𝓔𝓔\boldsymbol{\mathcal{E}}, for a given α𝛼\alpha and β𝛽\beta, in a binary classification fashion, by assigning binary scores P^α,jsubscript^𝑃𝛼𝑗\widehat{P}_{\alpha,j}, A^j∈{0,1}subscript^𝐴𝑗01\widehat{A}_{j}\in\{0,1\} to each synthetic sample X~g,jsubscript~𝑋𝑔𝑗\widetilde{X}_{g,j} in 𝒟s​y​n​t​hsubscript𝒟𝑠𝑦𝑛𝑡ℎ\mathcal{D}_{synth}, and R^β,i∈{0,1}subscript^𝑅𝛽𝑖01\widehat{R}_{\beta,i}\in\{0,1\} to each real sample X~r,isubscript~𝑋𝑟𝑖\widetilde{X}_{r,i} in 𝒟r​e​a​lsubscript𝒟𝑟𝑒𝑎𝑙\mathcal{D}_{real}, then averaging over all samples, i.e., P^α=1m​∑jP^α,jsubscript^𝑃𝛼1𝑚subscript𝑗subscript^𝑃𝛼𝑗\widehat{P}_{\alpha}=\frac{1}{m}\sum_{j}\widehat{P}_{\alpha,j}, R^β=1n​∑iR^β,isubscript^𝑅𝛽1𝑛subscript𝑖subscript^𝑅𝛽𝑖\widehat{R}_{\beta}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i}\widehat{R}_{\beta,i}, A^=1m​∑jA^j^𝐴1𝑚subscript𝑗subscript^𝐴𝑗\widehat{A}=\frac{1}{m}\sum_{j}\widehat{A}_{j}. To assign binary scores to individual samples, we construct three binary classifiers fPsubscript𝑓𝑃f_{P}, fRsubscript𝑓𝑅f_{R}, fA:𝒳~→{0,1}:subscript𝑓𝐴→~𝒳01f_{A}:\widetilde{\mathcal{X}}\to\{0,1\}, where P^α,j=fP​(X^g,j)subscript^𝑃𝛼𝑗subscript𝑓𝑃subscript^𝑋𝑔𝑗\widehat{P}_{\alpha,j}=f_{P}(\widehat{X}_{g,j}), R^β,i=fR​(X^r,i)subscript^𝑅𝛽𝑖subscript𝑓𝑅subscript^𝑋𝑟𝑖\widehat{R}_{\beta,i}=f_{R}(\widehat{X}_{r,i}) and A^j=fA​(X^g,j)subscript^𝐴𝑗subscript𝑓𝐴subscript^𝑋𝑔𝑗\widehat{A}_{j}=f_{A}(\widehat{X}_{g,j}). We explain the operation of each classifier in what follows.

Precision and Recall classifiers (fpsubscript𝑓𝑝\boldsymbol{f_{p}} and fRsubscript𝑓𝑅\boldsymbol{f_{R}}). Based on definitions (4) and (5), both classifiers check if a sample resides in an α𝛼\alpha- (or β𝛽\beta-) support, i.e., fP​(X~g)=𝟏​{X~g∈𝒮^rα}subscript𝑓𝑃subscript~𝑋𝑔1subscript~𝑋𝑔subscriptsuperscript^𝒮𝛼𝑟f_{P}(\widetilde{X}_{g})=\boldsymbol{1}\{\widetilde{X}_{g}\in\widehat{\mathcal{S}}^{\alpha}_{r}\} and fR​(X~r)=𝟏​{X~r∈𝒮^gβ}subscript𝑓𝑅subscript~𝑋𝑟1subscript~𝑋𝑟subscriptsuperscript^𝒮𝛽𝑔f_{R}(\widetilde{X}_{r})=\boldsymbol{1}\{\widetilde{X}_{r}\in\widehat{\mathcal{S}}^{\beta}_{g}\}. Hence, the main difficulty in implementing fPsubscript𝑓𝑃f_{P} and fRsubscript𝑓𝑅f_{R} is estimating the supports 𝒮^rαsubscriptsuperscript^𝒮𝛼𝑟\widehat{\mathcal{S}}^{\alpha}_{r} and 𝒮^gβsubscriptsuperscript^𝒮𝛽𝑔\widehat{\mathcal{S}}^{\beta}_{g}—in fact, even if we know the exact distributions ℙrsubscriptℙ𝑟\mathbb{P}_{r} and ℙgsubscriptℙ𝑔\mathbb{P}_{g}, computing their α𝛼\alpha- and β𝛽\beta-supports is not straightforward as it involves solving the optimization problem in (2).

To address this challenge, we pre-process the real and synthetic data in a way that renders estimation of α𝛼\alpha-and β𝛽\beta-supports straightforward. The idea is to train the evaluation embedding ΦΦ\Phi so as to cast 𝒮rsubscript𝒮𝑟\mathcal{S}_{r} into a hypersphere with radius r𝑟r, and cast the distribution ℙrsubscriptℙ𝑟\mathbb{P}_{r} into an isotropic density concentrated around the center crsubscript𝑐𝑟c_{r} of the hypersphere. We achieve this by modeling ΦΦ\Phi as a one-class neural network trained with the following loss function: L=∑iℓi𝐿subscript𝑖subscriptℓ𝑖L=\sum_{i}\ell_{i}, where

ℓi=r2+1ν​max⁡{0,‖Φ​(Xr,i)−cr‖2−r2}.subscriptℓ𝑖superscript𝑟21𝜈0superscriptnormΦsubscript𝑋𝑟𝑖subscript𝑐𝑟2superscript𝑟2\displaystyle\ell_{i}=r^{2}+\frac{1}{\nu}\,\max\{0,\|\,\Phi(X_{r,i})-c_{r}\,\|^{2}-r^{2}\}. (8)

The loss is minimized over the radius r𝑟r and the parameters of ΦΦ\Phi; the output dimensions of ΦΦ\Phi, crsubscript𝑐𝑟c_{r} and ν𝜈\nu are viewed as hyperparameters (see Appendix). The loss in (8) is based on the seminal work on one-class SVMs in (Schölkopf et al., 2001), which is commonly applied to outlier detection problems, e.g., (Ruff et al., 2018). In a nutshell, the evaluation embedding squeezes real data into the minimum-volume hypersphere centered around crsubscript𝑐𝑟c_{r}, hence 𝒮rαsubscriptsuperscript𝒮𝛼𝑟\mathcal{S}^{\alpha}_{r} is estimated as:

𝒮^rα=𝑩(cr,r^α),r^α=Q^α{∥X~r,i−cr∥:1≤i≤n},\displaystyle\widehat{\mathcal{S}}^{\alpha}_{r}=\boldsymbol{B}(c_{r},\widehat{r}_{\alpha}),\,\,\widehat{r}_{\alpha}=\widehat{Q}_{\alpha}\{\|\widetilde{X}_{r,i}-c_{r}\|:1\leq i\leq n\},

where 𝑩​(c,r)𝑩𝑐𝑟\boldsymbol{B}(c,r) is a Euclidean ball with center c𝑐c and radius r𝑟r, and Q^αsubscript^𝑄𝛼\widehat{Q}_{\alpha} is the α𝛼\alpha-quantile function. The set of α𝛼\alpha-supports for ℙrsubscriptℙ𝑟\mathbb{P}_{r} corresponds to the set of concentric spheres with center crsubscript𝑐𝑟c_{r} and radii r^α,∀α∈[0,1]subscript^𝑟𝛼for-all𝛼01\widehat{r}_{\alpha},\,\forall\alpha\in[0,1]. Thus, fPsubscript𝑓𝑃f_{P} assigns a score 1 to a synthetic sample X~gsubscript~𝑋𝑔\widetilde{X}_{g} if it resides within the Euclidean ball 𝒮^rαsubscriptsuperscript^𝒮𝛼𝑟\widehat{\mathcal{S}}^{\alpha}_{r}, i.e., fp​(X~g)=𝟏​{‖X~g−cr‖≤r^α}subscript𝑓𝑝subscript~𝑋𝑔1normsubscript~𝑋𝑔subscript𝑐𝑟subscript^𝑟𝛼f_{p}(\widetilde{X}_{g})=\boldsymbol{1}\{\|\widetilde{X}_{g}-c_{r}\|\leq\widehat{r}_{\alpha}\}. Define cg=1m​∑jX~g,jsubscript𝑐𝑔1𝑚subscript𝑗subscript~𝑋𝑔𝑗c_{g}=\frac{1}{m}\sum_{j}\widetilde{X}_{g,j}, and consider a hypersphere 𝑩​(cg,r^β)𝑩subscript𝑐𝑔subscript^𝑟𝛽\boldsymbol{B}(c_{g},\widehat{r}_{\beta}), where r^β=Q^β{∥X~g,j−cg∥:1≤j≤m}\widehat{r}_{\beta}=\widehat{Q}_{\beta}\{\|\widetilde{X}_{g,j}-c_{g}\|:1\leq j\leq m\}. We construct fRsubscript𝑓𝑅f_{R} as:

fR​(X~r,i)=𝟏​{X~g,j∗β∈𝑩​(X~r,i,NNDk​(X~r,i))},subscript𝑓𝑅subscript~𝑋𝑟𝑖1subscriptsuperscript~𝑋𝛽𝑔superscript𝑗𝑩subscript~𝑋𝑟𝑖subscriptNND𝑘subscript~𝑋𝑟𝑖\displaystyle f_{R}(\widetilde{X}_{r,i})=\boldsymbol{1}\{\widetilde{X}^{\beta}_{g,j^{*}}\in\boldsymbol{B}(\widetilde{X}_{r,i},\mbox{NND}_{k}(\widetilde{X}_{r,i}))\}, (9)

where X~g,j∗βsubscriptsuperscript~𝑋𝛽𝑔superscript𝑗\widetilde{X}^{\beta}_{g,j^{*}} is the synthetic sample in 𝑩​(cg,r^β)𝑩subscript𝑐𝑔subscript^𝑟𝛽\boldsymbol{B}(c_{g},\widehat{r}_{\beta}) closest to X~r,isubscript~𝑋𝑟𝑖\widetilde{X}_{r,i}, and NNDk​(X~r,i)subscriptNND𝑘subscript~𝑋𝑟𝑖\mbox{NND}_{k}(\widetilde{X}_{r,i}) is the distance between X~r,isubscript~𝑋𝑟𝑖\widetilde{X}_{r,i} and its k𝑘k-nearest neighbor in 𝒟r​e​a​lsubscript𝒟𝑟𝑒𝑎𝑙\mathcal{D}_{real}. (9) is a nonparametric estimate of 𝒮gβsubscriptsuperscript𝒮𝛽𝑔\mathcal{S}^{\beta}_{g} that checks if each real sample i𝑖i is locally covered by a synthetic sample in 𝑩​(cg,r^β)𝑩subscript𝑐𝑔subscript^𝑟𝛽\boldsymbol{B}(c_{g},\widehat{r}_{\beta}). A discussion on how to select the hyper-parameter k𝑘k, as well as an alternative method for estimating 𝒮gβsubscriptsuperscript𝒮𝛽𝑔\mathcal{S}^{\beta}_{g} using one-class representations is provided in the supplementary Appendix.

Authenticity classifier. We derive the classifier fAsubscript𝑓𝐴f_{A} from a hypothesis test that tests if a sample X~g,jsubscript~𝑋𝑔𝑗\widetilde{X}_{g,j} is non-memorized. Let ℋ1:Aj=1:subscriptℋ1subscript𝐴𝑗1\mathcal{H}_{1}:A_{j}=1 be the hypothesis that X~g,jsubscript~𝑋𝑔𝑗\widetilde{X}_{g,j} is authentic, with the null hypothesis ℋ0:Aj=0:subscriptℋ0subscript𝐴𝑗0\mathcal{H}_{0}:A_{j}=0. To test the hypothesis, we use the likelihood-ratio statistic (Van Trees, 2004):

Λ​(X~g,j)=ℙ​(X~g,j|Aj=1)ℙ​(X~g,j|Aj=0)=ℙg′​(X~g,j)δg,ϵ​(X~g,j),Λsubscript~𝑋𝑔𝑗ℙconditionalsubscript~𝑋𝑔𝑗subscript𝐴𝑗1ℙconditionalsubscript~𝑋𝑔𝑗subscript𝐴𝑗0subscriptsuperscriptℙ′𝑔subscript~𝑋𝑔𝑗subscript𝛿𝑔italic-ϵsubscript~𝑋𝑔𝑗\displaystyle\Lambda(\widetilde{X}_{g,j})=\frac{\mathbb{P}(\widetilde{X}_{g,j}\,|\,A_{j}=1)}{\mathbb{P}(\widetilde{X}_{g,j}\,|\,A_{j}=0)}=\frac{\mathbb{P}^{\prime}_{g}(\widetilde{X}_{g,j})}{\delta_{g,\epsilon}(\widetilde{X}_{g,j})}, (10)

which follows from (7). Since both likelihood functions in (10) are unknown, we need to devise a test for the hypothesis ℋ1:Aj=1:subscriptℋ1subscript𝐴𝑗1\mathcal{H}_{1}:A_{j}=1 that uses an alternative sufficient statistic with a known probability distribution.

Let dg,j=d​(X~g,j,𝒟r​e​a​l)subscript𝑑𝑔𝑗𝑑subscript~𝑋𝑔𝑗subscript𝒟𝑟𝑒𝑎𝑙d_{g,j}=d(\widetilde{X}_{g,j},\mathcal{D}_{real}) be the distance between synthetic sample j𝑗j and the training data set, and let i∗superscript𝑖i^{*} be the training sample in 𝒟r​e​a​lsubscript𝒟𝑟𝑒𝑎𝑙\mathcal{D}_{real} closest to Xg,jsubscript𝑋𝑔𝑗X_{g,j}, i.e., dg,j=d​(X~g,j,X~r,i∗)subscript𝑑𝑔𝑗𝑑subscript~𝑋𝑔𝑗subscript~𝑋𝑟superscript𝑖d_{g,j}=d(\widetilde{X}_{g,j},\widetilde{X}_{r,i^{*}}). Let dr,i∗subscript𝑑𝑟superscript𝑖d_{r,i^{*}} be the distance between X~r,i∗subscript~𝑋𝑟superscript𝑖\widetilde{X}_{r,i^{*}} and 𝒟r​e​a​l/{X~r,i∗}subscript𝒟𝑟𝑒𝑎𝑙subscript~𝑋𝑟superscript𝑖\mathcal{D}_{real}/\{\widetilde{X}_{r,i^{*}}\}, i.e., the training data with sample i∗superscript𝑖i^{*} removed. Now consider the statistic aj=𝟏​{dg,j≤dr,i∗}subscript𝑎𝑗1subscript𝑑𝑔𝑗subscript𝑑𝑟superscript𝑖a_{j}=\boldsymbol{1}\{d_{g,j}\leq d_{r,i^{*}}\}, which indicates if synthetic sample j𝑗j is closer to training data than any other training sample. The likelihood ratio for observations {aj}jsubscriptsubscript𝑎𝑗𝑗\{a_{j}\}_{j} under hypotheses ℋ0subscriptℋ0\mathcal{H}_{0} and ℋ1subscriptℋ1\mathcal{H}_{1} can be approximated as

Λ​(aj)=ℙ​(aj|Aj=1)ℙ​(aj|Aj=0)≈aj−1⋅ℙ​(dg,j≤dr,i∗|Aj=1).Λsubscript𝑎𝑗ℙconditionalsubscript𝑎𝑗subscript𝐴𝑗1ℙconditionalsubscript𝑎𝑗subscript𝐴𝑗0⋅subscriptsuperscript𝑎1𝑗ℙsubscript𝑑𝑔𝑗conditionalsubscript𝑑𝑟superscript𝑖subscript𝐴𝑗1\displaystyle\Lambda(a_{j})=\frac{\mathbb{P}(a_{j}\,|\,A_{j}=1)}{\mathbb{P}(a_{j}\,|\,A_{j}=0)}\approx a^{-1}_{j}\cdot\mathbb{P}(d_{g,j}\leq d_{r,i^{*}}\,|\,A_{j}=1).

Here, we used the fact that if sample j𝑗j is a memorized copy of i∗superscript𝑖i^{*}, and if the noise variance ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon in (7) is arbitrarily small, then aj=1subscript𝑎𝑗1a_{j}=1 almost surely and ℙ​(aj|Aj=0)≈1ℙconditionalsubscript𝑎𝑗subscript𝐴𝑗01\mathbb{P}(a_{j}\,|\,A_{j}=0)\approx 1. If j𝑗j is authentic, then X~g,jsubscript~𝑋𝑔𝑗\widetilde{X}_{g,j} lies in the convex hull of the training data, and hence ℙ​(aj|Aj=0)→0→ℙconditionalsubscript𝑎𝑗subscript𝐴𝑗00\mathbb{P}(a_{j}\,|\,A_{j}=0)\rightarrow 0 and Λ→∞→Λ\Lambda\rightarrow\infty for a large training set. Thus, fAsubscript𝑓𝐴f_{A} issues Aj=1subscript𝐴𝑗1A_{j}=1 if aj=0subscript𝑎𝑗0a_{j}=0, and Aj=0subscript𝐴𝑗0A_{j}=0 otherwise. Intuitively, fAsubscript𝑓𝐴f_{A} deems sample j𝑗j unauthentic if it is closer to i∗superscript𝑖i^{*} than any other real sample in the training data.

5 Experiments and Use Cases

5.1 Evaluating & auditing generative models for synthesizing COVID-19 data

In this experiment, we use our metric to assess the ability of different generative models to synthesize COVID-19 patient data that can be used for predictive modeling. Using SIVEP-Gripe (SIVEP-Gripe, 2020), a database of 99,557 COVID patients in Brazil, including sensitive data such as ethnicity. We use generative models to synthesize replicas of this data and fit predictive models to the replicas.

Models and baselines. We create 4 synthetic data sets using GAN, VAE, Wasserstein GANs with a gradient penalty (WGAN-GP) (Gulrajani et al., 2017), and ADS-GAN, which is specifically designed to prevent patient identifiablity in generated data (Yoon et al., 2020). To evaluate these synthetic data sets, we use Fréchet Inception Distance (FID) (Heusel et al., 2017), Precision/Recall (P1subscript𝑃1P_{1}/R1subscript𝑅1R_{1}) (Sajjadi et al., 2018), Density/Coverage (D𝐷D/C𝐶C) (Naeem et al., 2020), Parzen window likelihood (P​W𝑃𝑊PW) (Bengio et al., 2013) and Wasserstein distance (W𝑊W) as baselines. On each synthetic data set, we fit a (predictive) Logistic regression model to predict patient-level COVID-19 mortality.

Predictive modeling with synthetic data. In the context of predictive modeling, a generative model is assessed with respect to its usefulness in training predictive models that generalize well on real data. Hence, the “ground-truth” ranking of the 4 generative models corresponds to the ranking of the AUC-ROC scores achieved by predictive models fit to their respective synthetic data sets and tested on real data (Figure 4(a)). The data synthesized by ADS-GAN (×\boldsymbol{\times}) displayed the best performance, followed by WGAN-GP (∙∙\bullet), VAE (▲▲\blacktriangle), and GAN (■■\blacksquare). To assess the accuracy of baseline evaluation metrics, we test if each metric can recover the ground-truth ranking of the 4 generative models (Figure 4(a)). Our integrated precision and recall metrics I​Pα𝐼subscript𝑃𝛼IP_{\alpha} and I​Rβ𝐼subscript𝑅𝛽IR_{\beta} both assign the highest scores to ADS-GAN; I​Pα𝐼subscript𝑃𝛼IP_{\alpha} exactly nails the right ranking of generative models. On the other hand, competing metrics such as P1subscript𝑃1P_{1}, C𝐶C and D𝐷D, over-estimate the quality of VAE and WGAN-GP—if we use these metrics to decide which generative model to use, we will end up with predictive models that perform poorly, i.e. AUC-ROC of the predictive model fitted to synthetic data with best P1subscript𝑃1P_{1} is 0.55, compared to an AUC-ROC of 0.79 for our I​Pα𝐼subscript𝑃𝛼IP_{\alpha} score.

These results highlight the importance of accounting for the densities ℙgsubscriptℙ𝑔\mathbb{P}_{g} and ℙrsubscriptℙ𝑟\mathbb{P}_{r}, and not just their supports, when evaluating generative models. This is because a shifted ℙgsubscriptℙ𝑔\mathbb{P}_{g} would result in a “covariate shift” in synthetic data, leading to poor generalization for predictive models fitted to it, even when real and synthetic supports coincide. As shown in Figure 4(a), metrics that compare distributions (our metrics, P​W𝑃𝑊PW and F​I​D𝐹𝐼𝐷FID), accurately rank the 4 generative models.

Hyper-parameter tuning & the privacy-utility tradeoff. Another use case for our metric is hyper-parameter optimization for generative models. Here, we focus on the best-performing model in our previous experiment: ADS-GAN. This model has a hyper-parameter λ∈ℝ𝜆ℝ\lambda\in\mathbb{R} that determines the importance of the privacy-preservation loss function used to regularize the training of ADS-GAN (Yoon et al., 2020): smaller values of λ𝜆\lambda make the model more prone to overfitting, and hence privacy leakage. Figure 4(b) shows how our precision and authenticity metrics change with the different values of λ𝜆\lambda: the curve provides an interpretable tradeoff between privacy and utility (e.g., for λ=2𝜆2\lambda=2, an A𝐴A score of 0.4 means that 60%percent\% of patients may have personal information exposed). Increasing λ𝜆\lambda improves privacy at the expense of precision. By visualizing this tradeoff using our metric, data holders can understand the risks of different modeling choices involved in data synthesis.

Improving synthetic data via model auditing. Our metrics are not only useful for hyper-parameter tuning, but can also be used to improve the quality of synthetic data generated by an already-trained model using (post-hoc) auditing. Because our metrics are defined on the sample level, we can discard unauthentic or imprecise samples. This does not only lead to nearly optimal precision and authenticity for the curated data (Figure 4(c)), but also improves the AUC-ROC of the predictive model fitted to audited data (from 0.76 to 0.78 for the audited ADS-GAN synthetic data, p<0.005𝑝0.005p<0.005), since auditing eliminates noisy data points that would otherwise undermine generalization performance.

5.2 Diagnosing generative distributions of MNIST

In this experiment, we test the ability of our metrics to detect common modes of failure in generative modeling—in particular, we emulate a mode dropping scenario, where the generative model fails to recognize the distinct modes in a multimodal distribution ℙrsubscriptℙ𝑟\mathbb{P}_{r}, and instead recovers a single mode in ℙgsubscriptℙ𝑔\mathbb{P}_{g}. To construct this scenario, we fit a conditional GAN (CGAN) model (Wang et al., 2018) on the MNIST data set, and generate 1,000 samples for each of the digits 0-9. (We can think of each digit as a distinct mode in ℙrsubscriptℙ𝑟\mathbb{P}_{r}.) To apply mode dropping, we first sample 1,000 instances of each digit from the CGAN, and then delete individual samples of digits 1 to 9 with a probability Pd​r​o​psubscript𝑃𝑑𝑟𝑜𝑝P_{drop}, and replace the deleted samples with new samples of the digit 0 to complete a data set of 10,000 instances. The parameter Pd​r​o​p∈[0,1]subscript𝑃𝑑𝑟𝑜𝑝01P_{drop}\in[0,1] determines the severity of mode dropping: for Pd​r​o​p=0subscript𝑃𝑑𝑟𝑜𝑝0P_{drop}=0, the data set has all digits equally represented with 1,000 samples, and for Pd​r​o​p=1subscript𝑃𝑑𝑟𝑜𝑝1P_{drop}=1, the data set has 10,000 samples of the digit 0 only as depicted in Figure 5(a) (bottom panel).

We show how the different evaluation metrics respond to varying Pd​r​o​psubscript𝑃𝑑𝑟𝑜𝑝P_{drop} from 0 to 1 in Figure 5(a) (top). Because mode dropping pushes the generative distribution away from the real one, statistical distance metrics such as W𝑊W and F​I​D𝐹𝐼𝐷FID increase as Pd​r​o​psubscript𝑃𝑑𝑟𝑜𝑝P_{drop} approaches 1. However, these metrics only reflect a discrepancy between ℙrsubscriptℙ𝑟\mathbb{P}_{r} and ℙgsubscriptℙ𝑔\mathbb{P}_{g}, and do not disentangle the Fidelity and Diversity components of this discrepancy. On the other hand, standard precision and recall metric are completely insensitive to mode dropping except for the extreme case when Pd​r​o​p=1subscript𝑃𝑑𝑟𝑜𝑝1P_{drop}=1. This is because both metrics only check supports of ℙrsubscriptℙ𝑟\mathbb{P}_{r} and ℙgsubscriptℙ𝑔\mathbb{P}_{g}, so they cannot recognize mode dropping as long as there is a non-zero probability that the model will generates digits 1-9. On the contrary, mode dropping reflects in our metrics, which manifest in a declining I​Rβ𝐼subscript𝑅𝛽IR_{\beta} as Pd​r​o​psubscript𝑃𝑑𝑟𝑜𝑝P_{drop} increases. Since mode dropping affects coverage of digits and not the quality of images, it only affects I​Rβ𝐼subscript𝑅𝛽IR_{\beta} but not I​Pα𝐼subscript𝑃𝛼IP_{\alpha}.

5.3 Revisiting the Hide-and-Seek challenge for synthesizing time-series data

Finally, we use our metric to re-evaluate the generative models submitted to the NeurIPS 2020 Hide-and-Seek competition (Jordon et al., 2020). In this competition, participants were required to synthesize intensive care time-series data based on real data from the AmsterdamUMCdb database. A total of 16 submissions were judged based on the accuracy of predictive models fit to the synthetic data (an approach similar to the one in Section 5.1). The submissions followed various modeling choices, including recurrent GANs, autoencoders, differential privacy GANs, etc. Details of all submissions are available online. Surprisingly, the winning submission was a very simplistic model that adds Gaussian noise to the real data to create new samples.

To evaluate our metrics on time-series data, we trained a Seq-2-Seq embedding that is augmented with our One-class representations to transform time-series into fixed feature vectors. (The architecture for this embedding is provided in the Supplementary material.) In Figure 5(b), we evaluate all submissions with respect to precision, recall and authenticity. As we can see, the winning submission comes out as one of the least authentic models, despite performing competitively in terms of precision and recall. This highlights the detrimental impact of using naïve metrics for evaluating generative models—based on the competition results, clinical institutions seeking to create synthetic data sets may be led to believe that Submission 1 in Figure 5(b) is the right model to use. However, our metrics—which give a fuller picture of the true quality of all submissions—shows that such model creates unauthentic samples that are mere noisy copies of real data, which would pose risk to patient privacy. We hope that our metrics and our pre-trained Seq-2-Seq embeddings can help clinical institutions evaluate the quality of their synthetic time-series data in the future.

5.4 Image generation benchmarks

Finally, we use our metrics to evaluate the performance of two state-of-the-art image generation baselines: StyleGAN and diffusion probabilistic models. Particularly, we compare StyleGAN2-ADA (Karras et al., 2020) with denoising diffusion probabilistic models (DDPM) (Ho et al., 2020). We generate 10,000 samples from StyleGAN2-ADA and DDPM models pre-trained on the CIFAR-10 data set, and evaluate the I​Pα𝐼subscript𝑃𝛼IP_{\alpha} and I​Rβ𝐼subscript𝑅𝛽IR_{\beta} metrics for both samples with respect to ground-truth samples in the original CIFAR-10 data. The α𝛼\alpha- and β𝛽\beta-supports were evaluated on feature embeddings obtained using the pretrained Inception v3 model.

While the FID metric ranks StyleGAN2-ADA higher than DDPM, our metrics paint a more nuanced picture for the comparison between both models. We found that DDPM captures the distribution of the data better in region where the supports of the two models overlap, as evident by the superior I​Pα𝐼subscript𝑃𝛼IP_{\alpha} of DDPM. On the other hand, StyleGAN scores higher in the recall metric, indicating a better capturing of the diversity of images.

Implementation of our metric and code for all experiments is provided in github.com/ahmedmalaa/evaluating-generative-models and https://github.com/vanderschaarlab/evaluating-generative-models.

6 Conclusions

In this paper, we introduced a novel evaluation metric that characterizes the fidelity, diversity and generalization performance of generative models. Our metric is grounded in the notion of minimum volume sets, and enables both sample-level and distribution-level evaluation of the quality of a synthetic sample. We have demonstrated through several experiments that our evaluation metric is applicable to a wide variety of use cases and application domains.

We believe that the α𝛼\alpha-Precision, β𝛽\beta-Recall and authenticity metrics are particularly useful in clinical applications where both the accuracy of synthetic data distribution and the quality of individual samples are of great interest. The distinction between typical and outlier samples makes our precision and recall analysis well-suited for evaluating fairness of synthetic data, i.e., how well it represents patient subgroups. We leave the in-depth study of this use case for future work.

Appendix A: Literature Review

In this Section, we provide a comprehensive survey of prior work, along with a detailed discussion on how our metric relates to existing ones. We classify existing metrics for evaluating generative models into two main classes:

  1. 1.

    Statistical divergence metrics

  2. 2.

    Precision and recall metrics

Divergence metrics are single-valued measures of the distance between the real and generative distributions, whereas precision-recall metrics classify real and generated samples as to whether they are covered by generative and real distributions, respectively. In what follows, we list examples of these two types of metrics, highlighting their limitations.

Statistical divergence metrics.

The most straightforward approach for evaluating a generative distribution is to compute the model log-likelihood—for density estimation tasks, this has been the de-facto standard for training and evaluating generative models. However, the likelihood function is a model-dependent criteria: this is problematic because the likelihood of many state-of-the-art models is inaccessible. For instance, GANs are implicit likelihood models and hence provide no explicit expression for its achieved log-likelihood (Goodfellow et al., 2014). Other models, energy-based models has a normalization constant in the likelihood expression that is generally difficult to compute as they require solving intractable complex integrals (Kingma & Welling, 2013).

Statistical divergence measures are alternative (model-independent) metrics that are related to log-likelihood, and are commonly used for training and evaluating generative models. Examples include lower bounds on the log-likelihood (Kingma & Welling, 2013), contrastive divergence and noise contrastive estimation (Hinton, 2002; Gutmann & Hyvärinen, 2010), probability flow (Sohl-Dickstein et al., 2011), score matching (Hyvärinen et al., 2009), maximum mean discrepancy (MMD) (Gretton et al., 2012), and the Jensen-Shannon divergence (JSD).

In general, statistical divergence measures suffer from the following limitations. The first limitation is that likelihood-based measures can be inadequate in high-dimensional feature spaces. As has been shown in (Theis et al., 2015), one can construct scenarios with poor likelihood and great samples through a simple lookup table model, and vice versa, we can think of scenarios with great likelihood and poor samples. This is because, if the model samples white noise 99% of the time, and samples high-quality outputs 1% of the time, the log-likelihood will be hardly distinguishable from a model that samples high-quality outputs 100% of the time if the data dimension is large. Our metrics solve this problem by measuring the rate of error on a sample-level rather than evaluating the overall distribution of samples.

Moreover, statistical divergence measures collapse the different modes of failure of the generative distribution into a single number. This hinders our ability to diagnose the different modes of generative model failures such as mode dropping, mode collapse, poor coverage, etc.

Precision and recall metrics.

Precision and recall metrics for evaluating generative models were originally proposed in (Sajjadi et al., 2018). Our metrics differ from these metrics in various ways. First, unlike standard metrics, α𝛼\alpha-Precision and β𝛽\beta-Recall take into account not only the supports of ℙrsubscriptℙ𝑟\mathbb{P}_{r} and ℙgsubscriptℙ𝑔\mathbb{P}_{g}, but also the actual probability densities of both distributions. Standard precision (and recall) correspond to one point on the Pαsubscript𝑃𝛼P_{\alpha} (and Rβsubscript𝑅𝛽R_{\beta}) curve; they are equal to Pαsubscript𝑃𝛼P_{\alpha} and Rβsubscript𝑅𝛽R_{\beta} evaluated on the full support (i.e., P1subscript𝑃1P_{1} and R1subscript𝑅1R_{1}). By defining our metrics with respect to the α𝛼\alpha- and β𝛽\beta-supports, we do not treat all samples equally, but rather assign higher importance to samples that land in “denser” regions of 𝒮rsubscript𝒮𝑟\mathcal{S}_{r} and 𝒮gsubscript𝒮𝑔\mathcal{S}_{g}. Hence, Pαsubscript𝑃𝛼P_{\alpha} and Rβsubscript𝑅𝛽R_{\beta} reflect the extent to which ℙrsubscriptℙ𝑟\mathbb{P}_{r} and ℙgsubscriptℙ𝑔\mathbb{P}_{g} are calibrated—i.e., good Pαsubscript𝑃𝛼P_{\alpha} and Rβsubscript𝑅𝛽R_{\beta} curves are achieved when ℙrsubscriptℙ𝑟\mathbb{P}_{r} and ℙgsubscriptℙ𝑔\mathbb{P}_{g} share the same modes and not just a common support. While optimal R1subscript𝑅1R_{1} and P1subscript𝑃1P_{1} can be achieved by arbitrarily mismatched ℙrsubscriptℙ𝑟\mathbb{P}_{r} and ℙgsubscriptℙ𝑔\mathbb{P}_{g}, our Pαsubscript𝑃𝛼P_{\alpha} and Rβsubscript𝑅𝛽R_{\beta} curves are optimized only when ℙrsubscriptℙ𝑟\mathbb{P}_{r} and ℙgsubscriptℙ𝑔\mathbb{P}_{g} are identical as stated by Theorem 1.

The new Pαsubscript𝑃𝛼P_{\alpha} and Rβsubscript𝑅𝛽R_{\beta} metrics address the major shortcomings of precision and recall. Among these shortcomings are: lack of robustness to outliers, failure to detect matching distributions, and inability to diagnose different types of distributional failure (such as mode collapse, mode invention, or density shifts) (Naeem et al., 2020). Basically, a model ℙgsubscriptℙ𝑔\mathbb{P}_{g} will score perfectly on precision and recall (R1subscript𝑅1R_{1}=P1subscript𝑃1P_{1}=1) as long as it nails the support of ℙrsubscriptℙ𝑟\mathbb{P}_{r}, even if ℙrsubscriptℙ𝑟\mathbb{P}_{r} and ℙgsubscriptℙ𝑔\mathbb{P}_{g} place totally different densities on their common support.

In addition to the above, our metrics estimate the supports of real and generative distributions using neural networks rather than nearest neighbor estimates as in (Naeem et al., 2020). This prevents our estimates from overestimating the supports of real and generative distributions, thereby overestimating the coverage or quality of the generated samples.

Appendix B: Proof of Theorem 1

To prove the statement of the Theorem, we need to prove the two following statements:

(1) ℙg=ℙr→Pα/α=Rβ/β=1,∀α,βformulae-sequencesubscriptℙ𝑔subscriptℙ𝑟→subscript𝑃𝛼𝛼subscript𝑅𝛽𝛽1for-all𝛼𝛽\mathbb{P}_{g}=\mathbb{P}_{r}\,\,\rightarrow\,\,P_{\alpha}/\alpha=R_{\beta}/\beta=1,\,\forall\alpha,\beta

(2) Pα/α=Rβ/β=1,∀α,β→ℙg=ℙrformulae-sequencesubscript𝑃𝛼𝛼subscript𝑅𝛽𝛽1→for-all𝛼𝛽subscriptℙ𝑔subscriptℙ𝑟P_{\alpha}/\alpha=R_{\beta}/\beta=1,\,\forall\alpha,\beta\,\,\rightarrow\mathbb{P}_{g}=\mathbb{P}_{r}

Pα=ℙ​(X~g∈𝒮rα)=ℙ​(X~g∈𝒮gα)=α,subscript𝑃𝛼ℙsubscript~𝑋𝑔subscriptsuperscript𝒮𝛼𝑟ℙsubscript~𝑋𝑔subscriptsuperscript𝒮𝛼𝑔𝛼\displaystyle P_{\alpha}=\mathbb{P}(\widetilde{X}_{g}\in\mathcal{S}^{\alpha}_{r})=\mathbb{P}(\widetilde{X}_{g}\in\mathcal{S}^{\alpha}_{g})=\alpha, (11)

for all α∈[0,1]𝛼01\alpha\in[0,1], and similarly, we have

ℙ​(X~g∈𝒮rα)=∫𝒮rα𝑑ℙg=α,∀α∈[0,1].formulae-sequenceℙsubscript~𝑋𝑔subscriptsuperscript𝒮𝛼𝑟subscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝒮𝛼𝑟differential-dsubscriptℙ𝑔𝛼for-all𝛼01\displaystyle\mathbb{P}(\widetilde{X}_{g}\in\mathcal{S}^{\alpha}_{r})=\int_{\mathcal{S}^{\alpha}_{r}}d\mathbb{P}_{g}=\alpha,\,\forall\alpha\in[0,1]. (13)

Now assume that α′=α+Δ​αsuperscript𝛼′𝛼Δ𝛼\alpha^{\prime}=\alpha+\Delta\alpha, then we have

∫𝒮rα′/𝒮rα𝑑ℙg=∫𝒮rα′/𝒮rα𝑑ℙr=Δ​α.subscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝒮superscript𝛼′𝑟subscriptsuperscript𝒮𝛼𝑟differential-dsubscriptℙ𝑔subscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝒮superscript𝛼′𝑟subscriptsuperscript𝒮𝛼𝑟differential-dsubscriptℙ𝑟Δ𝛼\displaystyle\int_{\mathcal{S}^{\alpha^{\prime}}_{r}/\mathcal{S}^{\alpha}_{r}}d\mathbb{P}_{g}=\int_{\mathcal{S}^{\alpha^{\prime}}_{r}/\mathcal{S}^{\alpha}_{r}}d\mathbb{P}_{r}=\Delta\alpha. (14)

Thus, the probability masses of ℙgsubscriptℙ𝑔\mathbb{P}_{g} and ℙrsubscriptℙ𝑟\mathbb{P}_{r} are equal for all infinitesimally small region 𝒮rα+Δ​α/𝒮rαsubscriptsuperscript𝒮𝛼Δ𝛼𝑟subscriptsuperscript𝒮𝛼𝑟\mathcal{S}^{\alpha+\Delta\alpha}_{r}/\mathcal{S}^{\alpha}_{r} (for Δ​α→0→Δ𝛼0\Delta\alpha\rightarrow 0) of the α𝛼\alpha-support of ℙrsubscriptℙ𝑟\mathbb{P}_{r}, hence ℙg=ℙrsubscriptℙ𝑔subscriptℙ𝑟\mathbb{P}_{g}=\mathbb{P}_{r} for all subsets of 𝒮r1subscriptsuperscript𝒮1𝑟\mathcal{S}^{1}_{r}. By applying the similar argument to the recall metric, we also have ℙg=ℙrsubscriptℙ𝑔subscriptℙ𝑟\mathbb{P}_{g}=\mathbb{P}_{r} for all subsets of 𝒮g1subscriptsuperscript𝒮1𝑔\mathcal{S}^{1}_{g}, and hence ℙg=ℙrsubscriptℙ𝑔subscriptℙ𝑟\mathbb{P}_{g}=\mathbb{P}_{r}.

Appendix C: Alternative approach for estimating the support of synthetic data & code snippets

Instead of using a k𝑘k-NN approach to estimate the generative support 𝒮gβsuperscriptsubscript𝒮𝑔𝛽\mathcal{S}_{g}^{\beta}, one could use a separate one-class representation ΦgsubscriptΦ𝑔\Phi_{g} for each new synthetic sample being evaluated. We provide code snippets and comparisons between the two approaches in the an anonymized Colab notebook. While the two approaches perform rather similarly, we opt to adopt the k𝑘k-NN based approach to avoid potential biases induced by using a separate representation for each generative model when using our metric for model comparisons.

Appendix D: Experimental details

.1 Data

In this research the argue for the versatility of our metrics, hence we have included results for tabular (static), time-series and image data (see Table 2). For the tabular data we use (Baqui et al., 2020)’s preprocessed version of the SIVEP-GRIPE dataset of Brazilian ICU Covid-19 patient data. For the image experiments, we use the 10,000 samples in the default MNIST test set (LeCun, 1998). For proper evaluation of the authenticity metric, the same original data is used for training of generative models and evaluation of all metrics.

For the time-series experiments, AmsterdamUMCdb is used in a manner exactly analogous to the NeurIPS 2020 Hide-and-Seek Privacy Challenge (Jordon et al., 2020), which describes it as follows: “AmsterdamUMCdb was developed and released by Amsterdam UMC in the Netherlands and the European Society of Intensive Care Medicine (ESICM). It is the first freely accessible comprehensive and high resolution European intensive care database. It is also first to have addressed compliance with General Data Protection Regulation […] AmsterdamUMCdb contains approximately 1 billion clinical data points related to 23,106 admissions of 20,109 unique patients between 2003 and 2016. The released data points include patient monitor and life support device data, laboratory measurements, clinical observations and scores, medical procedures and tasks, medication, fluid balance, diagnosis groups and clinical patient outcomes.”. Notably, only the longitudinal features from this database are kept, with static ones discarded. The same subset as was used in the competition for “hider” synthetic data generation is used; this consists of 7695 examples with 70 features (and a time column), sequence length is limited to 100 (the original data contains sequences of up to length 135,337). The features are normalised to [0,1]01[0,1] and imputed as follows: (1) back-fill, (2) forward-fill, (3) feature median imputation. This preprocessing is chosen to match the competition (Jordon et al., 2020). The competition “hider” submissions were trained on this dataset and the synthetic data generated.

For metric consistency and the avoidance of tedious architecture optimization for each data modality, we follow previous works (e.g. (Heusel et al., 2017; Sajjadi et al., 2018; Kynkäänniemi et al., 2019; Naeem et al., 2020)) and embed image and time series data into a static embedding. This is required, since the original space is non-euclidean and will result in failure of most metrics. The static embedding is used for computing baseline metrics, and is used as input for the One-Class embedder.

For finding static representations of MNIST, images are upscaled and embedded using InceptionV3 pre-trained on ImageNET without top layer. This is the same embedder used for computing Fréchet Inception Distance (Heusel et al., 2017). Very similar results were obtained using instead a VGG-16 embedder (Brock et al., 2018; Kynkäänniemi et al., 2019). Preliminary experimentation with random VGG-16 models (Naeem et al., 2020) did not yield stable results for neither baselines nor our methods.

.2 Time series embedding

The time series embeddings used throughout this work are based on Unsupervised Learning of Video Representations using LSTMs (Srivastava et al., 2015), specifically the “LSTM Autoencoder Mode”. A sequence-to-sequence LSTM network is trained, with the target sequence set as the input sequence (reversed for ease of optimization), see Figure 6. The encoder hidden and cell states (hℎh and c𝑐c vectors) at the end of a sequence are used as the learned representation and are passed to the decoder during training. At inference, these are concatenated to obtain one fixed-length vector per example.

The specifics of the LSTM autoencoder used here are as follows. Two LSTM layers are used in each encoder and decoder. The size of h,cℎ𝑐h,c vectors is 707070 (280280280 after concatenation). The model was implemented in PyTorch (Paszke et al., 2017), utilising sequence packing for computational efficiency. All autoencoders were trained to convergence on the original data; the synthetic time series data was passed through this at inference. The time column (when present in data) was discarded.

.3 Full results

Table 3 contains metrics computed on different generated versions of the SIVEP-GRIPE tabular dataset. Included metrics are Wasserstein distance, Fréchet Distance (F​D𝐹𝐷FD), Parzen window likelihood estimate, precision P1subscript𝑃1P_{1}, recall R1subscript𝑅1R_{1}, density (D𝐷D), coverage C𝐶C and the proposed metrics, specifically integrated α𝛼\alpha-precision I​Pα𝐼subscript𝑃𝛼IP_{\alpha}, integrated β𝛽\beta-recall I​Rβ𝐼subscript𝑅𝛽IR_{\beta} and authenticity A𝐴A . For the tabular data, data is generated using a VAE, GAN, Wasserstein GAN with gradient penalisation (WGAN-GP) (Arjovsky et al., 2017), ADS-GAN (Yoon et al., 2020), Differentially Private GAN (DP-GAN) (Xie et al., 2018) and an ADS-GAN generated dataset in which samples are audited on precision and authenticity. Similarly, Table 4 contains metric results111Note that here, the Fréchet Distance equals the Fréchet Inception Distance, because the metrics are computed on InceptionV3 embeddings of the image data. for MNIST, generated by a VAE, Deep convolution GAN (DCGAN), WGAN-GP and ADS-GAN. Table 5 contains results for MIMIC generation using different methods from the Hide-and-Seek Privacy Competition (Jordon et al., 2020). The submission that won the competition is the penultimate model, Hamada. The last row shows results for an audited version of the Hamada dataset, in which we keep generating data using the Hamada model and discard samples that do not meet the precision or authenticity threshold.

.4 Hyperparameter optimization

.4.1 Baselines

For computing the density and coverage metrics, we set a threshold of 0.95 on the minimum expected coverage, as recommended in the original work (Eq. 9 (Naeem et al., 2020)). For all datasets, this is achieved for k=5𝑘5k=5. For consistency in these comparisons, we use k=5𝑘5k=5 for the precision and recall metrics too.

.4.2 OneClass embeddings

We use Deep SVDD (Ruff et al., 2018) to embed static data into One-Class representations. To mitigate hypersphere collapse (Propostions 2 and 3 of (Ruff et al., 2018)), we do not include a bias term and use ReLU activation for the One-Class embedder. Original data is split into training (80%) and validation (20%) set, and One-Class design is fine-tuned to minimise validation loss. We use the SoftBoundary objective (Eq. 3 (Ruff et al., 2018)) with ν=0.01𝜈0.01\nu=0.01 and center 𝐜=𝟏𝐜1\mathbf{c}=\mathbf{1} for tabular and time-series data and 𝐜=10⋅𝟏𝐜⋅101\mathbf{c}=10\cdot\mathbf{1} for image data. Let nhsubscript𝑛ℎn_{h} be the number of hidden layers with each dhsubscript𝑑ℎd_{h} nodes, and let dzsubscript𝑑𝑧d_{z} be the dimension of the representation layer. For tabular data, we use nh=3subscript𝑛ℎ3n_{h}=3, dh=32subscript𝑑ℎ32d_{h}=32 and dz=25subscript𝑑𝑧25d_{z}=25; for time-series data, nh=2subscript𝑛ℎ2n_{h}=2, dh=128subscript𝑑ℎ128d_{h}=128 and dz=32subscript𝑑𝑧32d_{z}=32; and for MNIST nh=3subscript𝑛ℎ3n_{h}=3, dh=128subscript𝑑ℎ128d_{h}=128 and dz=32subscript𝑑𝑧32d_{z}=32. Models are implemented in PyTorch (Paszke et al., 2017) and the AdamW optimizer is used with weight decay 10−2superscript10210^{-2}.

For the β𝛽\beta-recall metric, estimating the support of synthetic data involves tuning the k𝑘k parameter of the k𝑘k-NN estimator. The k𝑘k parameter can be tuned by fitting the NN estimator on a portion of the data for every given k𝑘k, and then testing the recall on a held out (real) sample. The selected k𝑘k for each α𝛼\alpha is the smallest k𝑘k that covers α𝛼\alpha held out samples. Similar to (Naeem et al., 2020), we found that through this procedure, k=5𝑘5k=5 seems to come up as the optimal k𝑘k for most experiments.

.5 Toy experiments

We include two toy experiments that highlight the advantage of the proposed metrics compared to previous works. We focus our comparison on the improved precision and recall (Kynkäänniemi et al., 2019) and density and coverage (Naeem et al., 2020) metrics.

.5.1 Robustness to outliers

Naeem et al. (2020) showed that the precision and recall metrics as proposed by (Sajjadi et al., 2018; Kynkäänniemi et al., 2019) are not robust to outliers. We replicate toy experiments to show the proposed α𝛼\alpha-Precision and β𝛽\beta-Recall do not suffer the same fate.

Let X,Y∈ℝd𝑋𝑌superscriptℝ𝑑X,Y\in\mathbb{R}^{d} denote original and synthetic samples respectively, with original X∼N​(0,I)similar-to𝑋𝑁0𝐼X\sim N(0,I) and Y∼N​(μ,I)similar-to𝑌𝑁𝜇𝐼Y\sim N(\mu,I). We compute all metrics for μ∈[−1,1]𝜇11\mu\in[-1,1]. In this setting we conduct three experiments:

  1. 1.

    No outliers

  2. 2.

    One outlier in the real data at X=𝟏𝑋1X=\mathbf{1}

  3. 3.

    One outlier in the synthetic data at Y=𝟏𝑌1Y=\mathbf{1}

We set d=64𝑑64d=64 and both original and synthetic data we sample 100001000010000 points. Subsequent metric scores are shown in Figure

As can be seen, the precision and recall metrics are not robust to outliers, as just a single outlier has dramatic effects. The I​Pα𝐼subscript𝑃𝛼IP_{\alpha} and I​Rβ𝐼subscript𝑅𝛽IR_{\beta} are not affected, as the outlier does not belong to the α𝛼\alpha-support (or β𝛽\beta-support) unless α𝛼\alpha (or β𝛽\beta) is large.

.5.2 Mode resolution

The precision and recall metrics only take into account the support of original and synthetic data, but not the actual densities. The density and coverage metric do take this into account, but here we show these are not able to capture this well enough to distinguish similar distributions.

In this experiment we look at mode resolution: how well is the metric able to distinguish a single mode from two modes? Let the original distribution be a mixture of two gaussians that are separated by distance μ𝜇\mu and have σ=1𝜎1\sigma=1,

X∼12​N​(−μ2,1)+12​N​(+μ2,1)similar-to𝑋12𝑁𝜇2112𝑁𝜇21X\sim\frac{1}{2}N(-\frac{\mu}{2},1)+\frac{1}{2}N(+\frac{\mu}{2},1)

and let the synthetic data be given by

Y∼N​(0,1+μ2).similar-to𝑌𝑁01superscript𝜇2Y\sim N(0,1+\mu^{2}).

This situation would arise if a synthetic data generator fails to distinguish the two nodes, and instead tries to capture the two close-by modes of the original distribution using a single mode. We compute metrics for μ∈[0,5]𝜇05\mu\in[0,5].

As can be seen, neither P&R nor D&C notice that the synthetic data only consists of a single mode, whereas the original data consisted of two. The α𝛼\alpha-precision metric is able to capture this metric: for small α𝛼\alpha the α𝛼\alpha-support of the original distribution is centred around the two separated, and does not contain the space that separates the modes (i.e. the mode of the synthetic data).
